title: Brooch
markings: On underside; a quatrefoil maker or retailer's mark "L L & LD Co" over "SILVER."
provenance: 2013, Given to Cooper-Hewitt by owner Harry C. Sigman.
description: Horizontal brooch consisting of a central element oval in shape and enameled in green mottled with yellow, with pierced Celtic motifs on each side.
justification: Jewelry is one area where enamel and silver came together in British arts and crafts design to create strong design objects with broad appeal. The&nbsp;Celtic strapwork suggests the influence of Archibald Knox on the design of this piece. The strapwork surrounds a mottled green-yellow enamel oval, to create the impression of a sea creature. References to aquatic and plantlife elements abound in British arts and crafts design, but usually in a design that is more stylized and geometric than those of French Art Nouveau design that shared those themes.&nbsp; The unusual marking&nbsp;of just "silver" instead of hallmarks, may indicate that the pieces were made outside England or Scotland to a British design for retail there.&nbsp;&nbsp; Depicted in Mervyn Levy, Liberty Style: The Classic Years, 1898-1910, London, 1986, p. 130.

tombstone.epitaph: Brooch. Silver, enamel. Gift of Harry C. Sigman. 2013-21-23.
